result.hateful_meaning: [1] Used in 19th-century United States to refer to the Irish. [2] Sometimes used today in reference to white people in a manner similar to white trash or redneck. [3] Also refers to white youth that imitate urban black youth by means of clothing style, mannerisms, and slang speech. The 'w' at the start of wigger refers to the white person and the 'igger' refers to nigger, which is a racial slur for black people. [4] Also used by radical Quebecois in self-reference, as in the seminal 1968 book White Niggers of America.

A British (usually English) immigrant. Some claim it derives from 'Prisoner of Mother England' or 'Prisoner of Her Majesty', but it probably derives from pomegranate, rhyming slang for 'immigrant'. It is often used irreverently and is usually considered offensive. Many such migrants to Australia, such as Prime Minister Julia Gillard, call themselves 'ten pound poms', because they paid ten pounds for their passage to Australia between 1945 and 1972 under an assisted migration scheme. Often combined with an adjective, particularly whingeing pom, a reference to migrants who complained about their adopted country. Often used in a sporting (especially cricket and rugby) context, with liberal use of 'pom' and 'Aussie' being used by the media; the term is often seen as unoffensive in this context, and instead as light-hearted banter by those who use it, but still possibly as offensive by those whom it is directed at.
A non-Jewish man, especially one perceived to be anti-Semitic.
A Native American, from the Seminole tribe.
A person of Armenian descent.

Pejorative term used in Mainland China and Taiwan to denote foreigners, especially millitary enemies, such as riben guizi (Japanese devils, because of Second Sino-Japanese War) and meiguo guizi (American devils, because of Korean War).
A rural person of Chinese descent.
A Filipino, particularly having a Mexican and Chinese heritage.
Used by Cairenes to refer to inhabitants of Upper Egypt.

[1] An inconsequential person (typically lower class). [2] A Gypsy. [3] In Scotland, a member of the native community previously itinerant (but mainly now settled) who were reputed for their production of domestic implements from basic materials and for repair of the same items, being also known in the past as 'travelling tinsmiths'. The slur is possibly derived from a reputation for rowdy and alcoholic recreation. Often wrongly confused with Gypsy/Romany people.
An Australian Aboriginal woman.
Turkana slur for members of the Pokot ethnic community, from 'cattle thief'.
Dutch pejorative for a black person.
An emasculated male, or a male subjugated to a female
A word used in Mexico to denote a person of dark brown or black hair and of browner skin tones and/or Amerindian or Afro-Mexican origin
A word used in Mexico to denote a person of dark brown or black hair and of browner skin tones and/or Amerindian or Afro-Mexican origin
A black person.
A black person.
[1] A promiscuous woman. [2] An unattractive woman.
[1] A male homosexual. [2] A male prostitute. [3] A womanizer.
A word used in Mexico to denote a person of dark brown or black hair and of browner skin tones and/or Amerindian or Afro-Mexican origin
A pejorative word often used in Mexican Spanish to describe the bad-mannered and poorly educated people, no matter if its refers to a poor or high economic-class person.
Hindu, commonly used in Bangladesh.
A male homosexual
Bitch
mujer facil (a woman of loose morals)
A Canadian. Variation on the ubiquitous 'eh' and the word 'asshole'.
A word used in Mexico to denote a person of dark brown or black hair and of browner skin tones and/or Amerindian or Afro-Mexican origin
Literally 'butcher, butcher', as an incitement to violence.
A person of Indian or Middle Eastern descent, based on the perceived surfeit of immigrants driving cabs in the United States.
A black person.
A word used in Mexico to denote a person of fair complexion or with blond or red hair
A German (shortened from the French term caboche dure 'hard head' or 'stubborn').
A person of Indian descent, from the worship of cows.
A black person, meaning 'coal miner' in reference to dark skin
A Jewish person (first used in the 1930s).
In Canada, an Irish Catholic [19th century on; origin uncertain: perhaps from Dugan, an Irish surname].
South African slang for an Anglo-African.
A word used in Mexico to denote a person of fair complexion or with blond or red hair
Used by loyalists in Northern Ireland for members of the nationalist/Catholic/Gaelic community. Derived the Irish name Tadhg, often mistransliterated as Timothy.

[1] Australian aboriginal. Boong, pronounced with (like the vowel in bull), is related to the Australian English slang word bung, meaning dead; infected; or dysfunctional. From bung, to go bung 'Originally to die, then to break down, go bankrupt, cease to function [Ab. bong dead]'. Highly offensive. [2] In New Zealand, a Pacific Islander.

[1] Australian aboriginal. Boong, pronounced with (like the vowel in bull), is related to the Australian English slang word bung, meaning dead; infected; or dysfunctional. From bung, to go bung 'Originally to die, then to break down, go bankrupt, cease to function [Ab. bong dead]'. Highly offensive. [2] In New Zealand, a Pacific Islander.

From bung, to go bung 'Originally to die, then to break down, go bankrupt, cease to function [Ab. bong dead]'. Highly offensive. [2] In New Zealand, a Pacific Islander.

[1] Australian aboriginal. Boong, pronounced with (like the vowel in bull), is related to the Australian English slang word bung, meaning dead; infected; or dysfunctional. From bung, to go bung 'Originally to die, then to break down, go bankrupt, cease to function [Ab. bong dead]'. Highly offensive. [2] In New Zealand, a Pacific Islander.
A person of East Indian origin.
A Jewish person (first used in the 1930s).
Person of Mexican or Hispanic descent. This term is used by Sri Lankan diaspora living in USA.
Used by the Sinhala majority to refer to a person of Tamil origin. Even though the proper Sinhala noun to refer a Tamil ethic group is Demala, when used in this sense it is regarded as disrespectful.
Leftist
Enemy of Japan
(especially,  korean) foreigners resident in Japan

A person of Hispanic descent. First recorded use in 1915. Theories include from 'no spik English' (and spiggoty from the Chicano no speak-o t'e English), but common belief is that it is an abbreviation of 'Hispanic'.
A person of Asian ancestry, meaning 'thin eyed'
Swedish slur for a Norwegian
A Latvian person, used by Russian immigrants in Latvia
A hairy person of Jewish ancestry, from the Star Wars character, Chewbacca.
Korean slur for a Vietnamese person, from 'peanut'
[1] Term used in Eastern Europe for ethnic Hungarians living in different countries after WWI. [2] A Romanian who has moved to Transylvania (which used to be under Hungary), from 'without country'.
Term used in Malaysia and Singapore to denote a Bangladeshi person, with possible connotations of illegal and/or migrant labor
Term used in Malaysia and Singapore to denote an Indonesian, with possible connotations of illegal and/or migrant labor
Filipino term for a black person
Cantonese term for Caucasian, from 'white ghost'
A person of Chinese ancestry
A Jewish person. Four-by-two is Cockney rhyming slang for Jew.
Embu slur for a member of the Luo ethnic group, meaning 'uncircumcised'.
A black person. From the West African name Kwazi, often given to a child born on a Sunday.
A person of Lebanese descent.

A peson of German descent. Derived from the local name for Prussian. Used to describe any German since the establishment of a Prussian Garrison in Fortress Luxembourg in 1815. Still commonly used today but most popular with World War II survivors.
Luo slur for a member of the Kikuyu community, meaning 'thief'.
A Hebrew biblical term for 'Nation' or 'People'. By Roman times it had also acquired the meaning of 'non-Jew'. In English, usage may be controversial, it can be assigned pejoratively to non-Jews.
[1] An Alaskan. [2] An Inuit.
Used in Hawaii to denote a black person.
A person of German descent.
A black person (referencing stereotypical hair type).
White supremacist term for a black person.
A Jewish person (first used in the 1930s).
A Jewish person (first used in the 1930s).
A Jewish person (first used in the 1930s).
A person who has sold out their beliefs, referring to the Irish Potato famine when some Catholics converted to a Protestant faith in order to gain access to a free meal.
A person of Asian descent.
Bahadur, means brave, has become a derogatory term for Nepali servants.
An Argentinian.
Abbreviation for 'asian'
A child of illegal immigrants, particularly in the United States, from the notion of dropping an anchor for other family members to acquire citizenship
A Caucasian, particularly an American
A person of Chinese ancestry
An Italian.
A Korean.
A Korean.
A Korean.
An American.
An American, denoting racist or fascist stereotypes
Pejorative term for African-Americans, from 'wild animal' or 'jackal'
Caucasian person who 'acts black'
Combination of American and 'coon'
Combination of African and 'coon'.
Arabic slur for a black person, from 'slave'
Arabic slur for a black person, from 'slave'

Pejorative term used in south of Mainland China and Hong Kong to denote a white man. Loosely translated as 'foreign devil;' more literally, might be 'ghost dude/bloke/guy/etc.' Gwei means 'ghost.' The color white is associated with ghosts in China. A lo is a regular guy (i.e. a fellow, a chap, or a bloke). Once a mark of xenophobia, the word is now in general, informal use but still considered derogatory.
The name fryc, plural fryce (after 'Fritz', short for Friedrich/Frederick), widely considered as typically German, is sometimes used as a noun for Germans.
